name: Executive Vocabulary
description: 30 sophisticated words for business and leadership

words.definition: Departing from an accepted standard; divergent.
Difficult to understand; obscure.
examples: The abstruse theory confused most readers.
His abstruse writing style limited his audience.

words.definition: Angry and bitter in tone or manner.
Report or represent in outline; foreshadow.
examples: The report adumbrated future policy changes.
Her remarks adumbrated the coming crisis.

words.definition: Not likely to provoke dissent; inoffensive.
Of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood; ridiculously old-fashioned.
examples: His antediluvian views were out of touch.
The antediluvian technology was finally replaced.

words.definition: Rough and bad-mannered; coarse.
examples: The boorish guest insulted the host.

words.definition: Slightly salty, as in estuaries; distasteful.
examples: His brackish humor offended some listeners.

words.definition: Self-assertive in a rude way.
Young and inexperienced.
examples: The callow intern made several mistakes.

words.definition: The use of trickery to achieve a political or legal purpose.
examples: The election was marred by chicanery.

words.definition: Slow to act; intended to cause delay.
Insolent or impertinent behavior.
examples: She had the effrontery to demand a raise.

words.definition: Mental calmness and evenness of temper.
examples: His equanimity under pressure was admirable.

words.definition: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
examples: Her erudite commentary enriched the discussion.

words.definition: Irritable and quarrelsome.
Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
examples: The garrulous neighbor talked for hours.
His garrulous nature tried everyone's patience.

words.definition: Relevant to a subject under consideration.
examples: Her comments were germane to the discussion.
Please keep remarks germane to the topic.

words.definition: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner.
examples: The grandiloquent prose obscured the message.

words.definition: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
examples: The team suffered an ignominious defeat.
His ignominious exit ended his career.

words.definition: Unable to be appeased or placated.
examples: She was an implacable opponent of the policy.

words.definition: Lacking flavor or vigor; dull.
Unwilling to change one's views or agree.
Having a sharply critical quality; biting.
examples: The critic's mordant review devastated the artist.

words.definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion.
Unwilling to spend money; stingy.
examples: The parsimonious boss rarely gave raises.
Her parsimonious habits bordered on miserly.

words.definition: The presence of something in only small quantities; scarcity.
examples: The paucity of resources hampered progress.

words.definition: Cause to happen suddenly or prematurely.
examples: Don't precipitate a crisis with hasty action.

words.definition: Showing great attention to detail or correct behavior.
Bitter and abusive.
